title: 108_s2414
content: The Act titled "Federal Inmate Work Opportunities Review Commission" creates a commission to review federal inmate work opportunities. The Federal Inmate Work Opportunities Review Commission is established with 9 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and minority leader of the House of Representatives. The Federal Inmate Work Opportunities Review Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in the Senate and House of Representatives based on party affiliation. Each member must have knowledge or expertise in relevant matters and serves for the duration of the Commission. The Federal Inmate Work Opportunities Review Commission consists of 9 members appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled within 60 days. The President appoints a chairperson within 15 days of all members' appointments. Meetings are called by the chairperson, with the initial meeting within 30 days of member appointments. A majority of members forms a quorum for the Commission. The Commission requires a majority of members to form a quorum for conducting business and may establish a lesser quorum for hearings. Rules for Commission business can be established by majority vote. The Commission's duties include examining Federal Prison Industries' impact on the correctional mission and private labor markets. The Commission's duties include examining the impact of Federal Prison Industries on the correctional mission and private labor markets. This involves assessing the number of inmates employed by Federal Prison Industries, exploring alternatives to maximize inmate work opportunities while minimizing job displacement in the private sector, and studying other relevant issues as determined by the Commission. The Commission will submit a report on the study carried out under this Act, including findings, conclusions, and recommended legislation for reforming Federal prison work programs to the President, Congress, Judiciary Committees, and the Attorney General within 2 years of its initial meeting. The Commission may hold hearings, request witnesses and documents, issue subpoenas, and enforce compliance for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of the Act regarding Federal prison work programs. The Attorney General can enforce a subpoena in federal court if there is refusal to obey. Documents obtained through a subpoena cannot be released publicly without a 2/3 vote from the Commission. The Commission must consider the opinions of relevant parties, including private sector businesses and labor unions, regarding inmate work programs. The Commission members serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses. Federal employees can be detailed with a 2/3 vote from the Commission. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement with approval from the head of the agency. The detail does not interrupt civil service status, benefits, or privileges. The Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services to the Commission as needed. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting required reports. Sums may be appropriated for Act implementation.
